quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: You're managing a healthcare software project. Your team (Domain 2) is skilled but lacks clarity on their roles. Stakeholders (Domain 1) have conflicting requirements. The schedule (Domain 5) is aggressive. Customer feedback (Domain 7) shows the solution isn't meeting their needs. Risk of regulatory non-compliance (Domain 8) is high.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: Which domain should you address FIRST to create the biggest positive impact?

options.A: Domain 5 (Planning) - Create a detailed schedule to show progress
options.B: Domain 1 (Stakeholders) - Align stakeholders on requirements and priorities
options.D: Domain 7 (Measurement) - Set up more metrics to track performance

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Domain 1 (Stakeholders) - Align stakeholders on requirements and priorities

insights.explanation: Without stakeholder alignment, all other domains suffer. Conflicting requirements create team confusion, planning chaos, and measurement against wrong targets.
insights.pmbokSupport: The Stakeholders domain addresses activities and functions associated with stakeholders. It's the foundation that enables all other domains.

insights.explanation: Addressing stakeholders cascades positive effects to Team (clear direction), Planning (agreed scope), and Measurement (right metrics).
insights.pmbokSupport: Performance domains are interactive, interrelated, and interdependent. Work in one domain affects others.

insights.explanation: Before planning how to deliver, you must align on what to deliver and why it matters.
insights.pmbokSupport: Understanding stakeholder needs and expectations is prerequisite to effective planning and execution.

trapSection.explanation: The other options address symptoms, not root causes.

trapTable.violation: Planning without clear requirements creates detailed plans for the wrong thing
Team building won't help if the team doesn't know what they're building
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Team needs direction before motivation helps

trapTable.violation: Measuring the wrong things precisely doesn't create value
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Measurement without aligned objectives is wasteful

patternRecognition.patternRule: When multiple domains have issues, address Stakeholders and Team first - they enable effective work in all other domains.

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: The 8 Performance Domains represent the critical areas of focus for project delivery. Think of them as 8 steps (STUPENI means 'steps' in Russian) climbing the mountain:

rows.action: Build relationships, manage expectations, engage throughout
Establish culture, develop people, create high-performing teams
keyQuestions: Do they have what they need?
rows.examKeywords: team development, culture, skills, empowerment, collaboration

rows.action: Select development approach and lifecycle (predictive, adaptive, hybrid)
rows.examKeywords: lifecycle, methodology, agile, waterfall, hybrid, cadence

rows.action: Organize and coordinate to deliver scope, maintain alignment
rows.examKeywords: schedule, budget, scope, baseline, estimates, WBS

rows.action: Establish processes, manage resources, focus on learning
Deliver scope, focus on value and quality
rows.examKeywords: deliverables, acceptance, value, quality, scope verification

rows.action: Assess performance, adapt as needed, report status
rows.examKeywords: KPIs, metrics, earned value, variance, performance reporting

rows.action: Identify risks and opportunities, respond to threats
rows.examKeywords: risk, threat, opportunity, contingency, response, ambiguity

coreFramework.additionalContent:

Stakeholders ‚Üí Team ‚Üí U (Development Approach) ‚Üí Planning ‚Üí Execution (Project Work) ‚Üí DeNivery ‚Üí MeasurIng ‚Üí Uncertainty

pmbokConnection.quote: Project performance domains are interactive and interrelated areas of focus that work in concert to achieve desired project outcomes.

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: These 8 domains represent WHAT work must be performed on projects. Unlike process groups (which describe WHEN), domains describe focus areas throughout the project.
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: All domains are important. When domains interact, think about cascading impacts across domains.
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Exam questions often span multiple domains. Look for answers that address the root cause domain, not just symptoms in other domains.
visualReferenceCard.pmbokPrinciple: PMBOK 7 - Performance domains replace the traditional 10 Knowledge Areas

secondScenario.title: Apply the STUPENI Framework
secondScenario.intro: Now that you know the framework, let's apply it to a new situation.
secondScenario.scenarioStory: Your agile project is 6 sprints in. Velocity is dropping (Measurement), team morale is low (Team), and the product owner keeps changing priorities (Stakeholders). The development approach feels wrong for this project (Development Approach).
secondScenario.question: Which domains should you address to turn this around? (Select the BEST approach)

options.A: Measurement - Focus on improving velocity metrics
options.B: Stakeholders & Development Approach - Re-align on priorities and confirm agile is right fit
options.C: Team - Conduct team building to improve morale
options.D: Delivery - Push to release something quickly to show progress

quotes.text: The eight performance domains are interactive and interdependent. They are not discrete, independent elements of work. Work in one domain enables performance in another domain, and performance in one domain can constrain another domain.
quotes.author: PMI

quotes.text: On the exam, they won't tell you which domain is being tested. You need to recognize the underlying issue. Is it a stakeholder problem? A team problem? Think about root causes, not symptoms. A schedule issue might actually be a stakeholder alignment problem.
quotes.author: PMP Instructor Insight

fieldInsights.title: Real-World Application
fieldInsights.insight: Experienced PMs know that fixing one domain often requires work in another. Can't deliver value (Delivery) if stakeholders aren't aligned (Stakeholders). Can't execute well (Project Work) if the team lacks skills (Team). The domains are a system.

fieldInsights.title: Exam Strategy
fieldInsights.insight: When a scenario shows problems in multiple domains, identify the root cause domain. Stakeholder and Team issues often cascade to other domains. Addressing these foundational domains creates positive ripple effects.

memoryPalace.title: üèîÔ∏è Memory Palace: The 8 Base Camps
memoryPalace.intro: Your mountain has 8 base camps (STUPENI = steps in Russian). As you climb, you pass through each domain:

story.title: The 8-Camp Summit Journey
story.narrative: To reach the summit, you must pass through 8 base camps. Each camp represents a performance domain. Skip a camp, and your summit attempt fails.

scenes.description: At the trailhead, you meet all expedition STAKEHOLDERS - sponsors, climbers, guides, local communities. You listen to their needs, manage expectations, and build relationships. Without their buy-in, you can't even start climbing.
Camp 1 is where your TEAM assembles. You assign roles (lead climber, medic, navigator), develop skills, and build trust. A dysfunctional team won't survive the climb.

At Camp 2, you choose your DEVELOPMENT APPROACH. Direct route to summit (waterfall/predictive)? Or adaptive approach with multiple camps and route adjustments (agile/adaptive)? The terrain dictates the approach.
Camp 3 is the PLANNING hub. You create schedules, estimate how much food/rope you need, break down the climb into stages (WBS), and establish baselines. Without a plan, chaos reigns.
Camp 4 is where the real WORK happens. You execute your plan, manage physical resources (ropes, oxygen), establish processes (daily check-ins), and learn from each day's climb.

Camp 5 focuses on DELIVERY. Are you delivering value? Are you making progress toward the summit (scope)? Does the route meet quality standards (safe anchors, tested ropes)? Are stakeholders satisfied with progress?

At Camp 6, you MEASURE performance. How's your pace? Are you on schedule? Altitude sickness rates (quality metrics)? Oxygen consumption vs. plan (earned value)? Measurement tells you if you need to adapt.

Camp 7 is the UNCERTAINTY headquarters. You continuously identify risks (avalanche, rockfall, weather), assess opportunities (better route discovered), and respond (contingency plans, risk reserves). Uncertainty never stops.

story.moral: You successfully summit because you attended to ALL 8 domains throughout the climb. Each camp (domain) supported the others. Neglect one domain, and the whole expedition suffers.

memoryPalace.selfTest: Close your eyes and climb through the 8 camps. Can you recall all 8 domains using STUPENI and the camp story?
